**Among the Trump Administration's first Pentagon cuts: Programs that respond to climate change**
The US military is set to cut its budget by 8% over the next five years, with climate change programs being an early target. However, national security experts argue that the Pentagon's climate change efforts are actually focused on warfare and not purely environmental purposes. Tom Ellison of the Center for Climate and Security notes that climate change will impact the military's ability to operate, including extreme heat and pollution affecting troop health, changes in ocean chemistry affecting submarine sonar, and changes in humidity affecting aircraft lift capacity. The military is also building resilience into its infrastructure planning, with some installations expected to be abandoned due to rising sea levels. Despite bipartisan support for the military's climate change efforts, the Defense Department has taken down its official climate resilience portal and has not responded to questions about which climate-related programs will be eliminated.

**Brazil Establishes National Day for Climate Action**
The Brazilian Chamber of Deputies has approved a bill that establishes April 27th as the National Day for Climate Action. The bill, proposed by Deputy Duda Salabert, aims to promote climate action and disaster preparedness among schools. **Trump and Project 2025: President's early moves mirror conservative playbook - National | Globalnews.ca**
Donald Trump's early executive orders in his second term align with many ideas promoted in Project 2025, a conservative policy agenda published by the Heritage Foundation in April 2023. Over 30 of Trump's 47 early executive orders show clear parallels with Project 2025, including ending certain international agreements, loosening environmental regulations, and scaling back on or dismantling diversity, equity and inclusion programs. Trump has repeatedly denied any involvement with Project 2025, but experts say it's likely that his team has searched for recommendations that align with his policies. Project 2025 proposed a freeze on 'all top career-position hiring' to 'prevent 'burrowing in' by outgoing political appointees,' which Trump's White House has ordered. The blueprint also recommended that Health and Human Services cancel programs that recognize transgender people and that the government withdraw all guidance to teens seeking 'gender-affirming care' or 'gender transition.' Trump has taken steps to implement these recommendations, including ending federal funding for gender-affirming care for minors and rescinding protections for transgender Americans to serve in the military. Project 2025 proposed ending programs designed to meet the Paris climate agreement, with the goal of ceasing a 'global, climate-themed agenda' and the 'perceived threat of climate change.' Trump's White House has started the process of withdrawing from the Paris climate agreement, including financial commitments and related agreements. 'Trump is, if nothing else, predictable. He'll do what makes him look like a winner and implementing the sweeping programs in Project 2025 is an easy pathway to looking like a winner,' said Aaron Ettinger, Associate Professor in the Department of Political Science at Carleton University.

**Putin Signs Decree on Call-up of Citizens in Reserve for Military Training in 2025**
Russian President Vladimir Putin has signed a decree to call up citizens in reserve for military training in 2025. According to the decree, published on the official portal of legal information, citizens in reserve will be called up for military training in the Armed Forces, National Guard, rescue units, state security, and federal security. The decree comes into effect on the day of publication. The government and regional authorities are tasked with ensuring the implementation of all measures related to the conduct of these training sessions. The training is aimed at improving combat readiness and is a planned annual event. Reservists can receive summons every three years in both paper and electronic form. The maximum duration of training is two months. Typically, the call-up of those in reserve occurs once a year. In 2023, Putin signed a decree on the call-up for military training on May 10, and in 2024, on March 1. As a reminder, the Russian Ministry of Defense also announced the end of the autumn conscription for military service on December 28. A total of 133,000 people were called up for military service, with the dispatch of conscripts from collection points beginning on October 15. The next, spring, conscription campaign will begin on April 1 and end on July 15. It is worth noting that significant amendments to the law 'On Military Obligation and Military Service' were adopted in the spring of 2023. At the same time, it was reported that the accounting of military personnel would be carried out automatically, and summons would be sent through 'Gosuslugi.' In December 2024, Putin instructed the Ministry of Defense to conduct the autumn conscription using the electronic register of military personnel and the register of summons. Head of the Defense Committee of the State Duma Andrei Kartapolov said that the previous autumn conscription was based on paper summons. According to him, electronic summons are currently being tested in three regions - the Riazan region, Mari El, and Sakhalin.
